meaning_mnemonic: If you run into a <radical>gate</radical> <radical>mouth</radical> first, you’re going to have a <kanji>problem</kanji>. Smashing your mouth into a gate is going to hurt. A lot. The problem you’re now in is one of getting to a hospital and having your mouth sewn back on. The <kanji>question</kanji> is, how are you going to get to the hospital?
The <radical>roof</radical> under which the <radical>leader</radical> can house one <radical>hundred</radical> of his people is at the local <kanji>lodge</kanji>.

Only a <radical>tree</radical> with <radical>eye</radical>s and a <radical>heart</radical> has the ability to <kanji>imagine</kanji> and to <kanji>contemplate</kanji>. For a tree to imagine and contemplate things, it needs eyes to see and a heart to feel.
When a <radical>canine</radical> puts its <radical>mouth</radical> on your <radical>heart</radical>, it's a pretty unforgettable <kanji>feeling</kanji>.

A <radical>bundle</radical> in <radical>winter</radical> is the <radical>correct</radical> way to <kanji>arrange</kanji> things. Just make sure you <kanji>organize</kanji> it all before winter comes, or it'll be too late.

If the <radical>sun</radical> starts to make a <radical>sound</radical>, you know it's about to go <kanji>dark</kanji>. The sun isn't supposed to make a sound, so if you can hear it, it's probably about to fizzle out or something. After it's gone, obviously everything will be pitch black. Get ready to be in the dark!

By a <radical>tree</radical>, there's a <radical>sheep</radical> in the <radical>water</radical> with a <kanji>formal name ender</kanji>. That means everyone calls him Sheep-sama. No one calls him just "Sheep," since he's kind of a big deal. He's actually like sheep royalty. When he's not in his castle, Sheep-sama enjoys playing in the water by the trees.

This can also mean <kanji>manner</kanji>, as in your manner of doing things. I guess someone with a formal name ender has a different manner of doing things.

This <radical>tree</radical> must've been sent from <radical>heaven</radical>, because it has a <radical>mouth</radical> and a <radical>mustache</radical>. Like some kind of special heaven tree that talks. And why was it sent? To be a <kanji>bridge</kanji>. To be the great heavenly bridge that we all, someday, must cross.

If you tie a <radical>thread</radical> around <radical>Wolverine</radical> and dip him in <radical>water</radical>, he'll turn <kanji>green</kanji>, like the Hulk. Some kind of weird chemical reaction. But I… I wouldn't try it if I were you. You wouldn't like him when he's green.

Pointing a <radical>thread</radical> to the <radical>east</radical> is what you <kanji>practice</kanji> every day. You're incredibly passionate about eastward thread-pointing, so you make sure to practice every day.

What you <radical>say</radical> at a <radical>temple</radical> is a <kanji>poem</kanji>. It has to be a poem, because if you say anything else it's just plain disrespectful. All of the monks and priests at this temple have to read and recite poems all day, and if they can do it forever, you can while you're visiting.

<radical>Gold</radical>, at its <radical>root</radical>, is made up of <kanji>silver</kanji>. Using silver as the root of a coin is a great way to save on gold! That's why, often, if you just scratch gold, you'll find there's silver hidden underneath, at its root.
If you use the <radical>sun</radical>, you can find the <radical>correct</radical> <radical>geoduck</radical>. That's the <kanji>topic</kanji> of today's lecture.

<radical>Eat</radical>ing the <radical>roof</radical> is a <radical>bear</radical>, because the roof is a <kanji>public building</kanji>. Because it is a public building bears are allowed to eat the roof.
A <radical>horse</radical> and a <radical>shrimp</radical> are sitting next to each other. They are both at the train <kanji>station</kanji>, waiting for a train to come and take them home.

A cult <radical>leader</radical> has a great <radical>idea</radical> to recruit a <kanji>hundred million</kanji> new members. Since he’s the guy with all the ideas, he is the leader of the cult. His idea is to give every new member a free puppy. He’ll have a hundred million new recruits in no time.

<radical>Big</radical> <radical>products</radical> need to be put in a big <kanji>container</kanji>. A small container just won’t do. These products are big and they need a big container to be contained in.
The <radical>samurai</radical> radical and the <kanji>samurai</kanji> kanji are the same!

You have a <radical>rice</radical> <radical>ladle</radical> that's specifically for paying the rice <kanji>fee</kanji>. Each scoop of something has an extra fee tacked on, so when you use a <kanji>material</kanji>, there's a fee you have to pay in that material as well.

You see a <radical>tree</radical> with a <radical>helicopter</radical> and a <radical>jackhammer</radical> tied to it. You look closer, because this is an odd sight, and realize that there is a sign here too. It's telling you to beware of helicopters and jackhammers in these woods. It's a poorly made <kanji>signpost</kanji>!
There's <radical>treasure</radical> in this <radical>tree</radical> so you take out your <radical>weapon</radical> and <kanji>kill</kanji> it.
Under a misshapen crescent <radical>moon</radical>, a <radical>dog</radical> <radical>boil</radical>s as much <kanji>nature</kanji> as it can find.
Your <radical>womb</radical> spins in a <radical>circle</radical> and starts to <radical>boil</radical> with <kanji>heat</kanji>. Uh oh, I think you have a <kanji>fever</kanji>.
I always <radical>say</radical> the <radical>fruit</radical> <kanji>section</kanji> at the grocery should be at the front of the store. It’s the perfect place for the fruit section, I say.
The <radical>Viking</radical> opens his <radical>mouth</radical>, and below it, a <radical>shellfish</radical> sits. Grab that shellfish and throw it into his mouth to win a <kanji>prize</kanji>!

For your <radical>car</radical> you use a <radical>hat</radical>, some <radical>ground</radical> and a <radical>bookshelf</radical> to build a new <kanji>wheel</kanji>. I mean, it's generally <kanji>ring</kanji> and <kanji>loop</kanji> shaped, it just needs to be a <kanji>circle</kanji>, so it should work, right?

You want to get a <radical>scooter</radical>, so you have one self (<radical>oneself</radical>) and another self working <radical>together</radical> to <kanji>choose</kanji>. The two tiny yous sit on each of your shoulders, like angel and devil, and argue about which scooter you should choose.

<radical>Gold</radical> reveals itself when you <radical>stand</radical> and <radical>see</radical> into this <kanji>mirror</kanji>. Yes, even you are made of gold. You're so great and valuable, standing in front of that mirror. It's not hard to see, especially in a mirror – you're golden.

<radical>Sheep</radical> <radical>fins</radical> are <radical>good</radical> for <kanji>foster</kanji> children. The sheep have been genetically combined with fish, so the sheep have fins (and they've lost their tails — which is why the tail part of the sheep radical is missing in this kanji). These sheep fins are rich in nutrients, so they're good for fostering big, strong foster children.

Your <radical>soul</radical> is <radical>blue</radical>. As in, it's sad and not feeling well. This is because your soul changes colors depending on your <kanji>feeling</kanji>s or what <kanji>emotion</kanji>s you're expressing.
You thought it would be a good idea to <radical>say</radical> the <radical>body</radical> <radical>measurement</radical>s of everyone in your village and now you have to <kanji>apologize</kanji>.

You reach for a <radical>spoon</radical> to start eating, but your <radical>mama</radical> hands you an <radical>arrow</radical> instead and points towards the <radical>coat rack</radical>. Hm, that's not like her… Suddenly you're filled with <kanji>doubt</kanji>. Is this really your mama? You doubt it.

If you <radical>compare</radical> <radical>white</radical> light to the other colors you'll realize... white consists of <kanji>all</kanji> the colors in one. It contains all the colors in the spectrum in one color. It is the one color that is <kanji>everything</kanji>.

The <radical>leader</radical> of a <radical>big</radical> <radical>rice paddy</radical> is standing in the middle of said rice paddy with an <radical>umbrella</radical>. Who is this wacky leader? Why, it is <kanji>I</kanji>. It is <kanji>me</kanji>.
The radical <radical>can</radical> is the same as the kanji <kanji>can</kanji>. Usually when we talk about a can with this kanji we mean a <kanji>tin can</kanji>, though.
